Award.AwardTitle: Effect of the Triaxial State of Stress in the Connectivity of Hydraulically-created Fractures in Crystalline Rocks

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is great potential in the use of hydraulic fracturing to increase the permeability of crystalline rock formations in Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) and Artificial Groundwater Recharge (AGR) applications. EGS has the potential of providing more than 100,000 MWe for the next 50 years in the United States; AGR is a method that enhances the recharge of wells at shallower depths, which may be particularly useful to increase the supply of clean water to populations in dry regions. In both applications, the rocks are hydraulically fractured in order to create a network of interconnected fractures that will increase the permeability of the stimulated formations. The lack of fracture connectivity after the hydraulic stimulations may lead to low, or insignificant, increases in the permeability of the hydraulically-fractured rock formations which, in turn, may result in financial losses and ultimately cause the abandonment of EGS and AGR projects without taking advantage of their full potential. Therefore, understanding the effect of field variables, such as the triaxial state of stress which will be investigated in this project, in fracture connectivity is of adamant importance to the success of these applications. This project will also engage and educate undergraduate and graduate as well as high-school students, on the fundamentals of hydraulic fracturing applied to EGS and AGR.

This project will 1) evaluate the effect of the triaxial state of stress in the connectivity between hydraulically-created and existing fractures in crystalline rocks, and 2) identify visual and acoustic emission (AE) precursors of rock failure due to hydraulic fracturing. In order to do so, an apparatus developed and previously used by the Principal Investigator in the hydraulic fracturing of prismatic granite specimens subject to a vertical load will be redesigned to allow one to apply a triaxial state of stress in prismatic rock specimens. Flaws pre-fabricated in these specimens will be pressurized with water leading to the propagation of hydraulic fractures. The entire fracturing process will be observed visually, using High-Resolution and High-Speed Video cameras, and by monitoring the acoustic emissions produced by the development of new fractures. By integrating the visualization with the AE-monitoring of the fracturing processes, it will be possible to evaluate the effect of the triaxial state of stress in the mode of fracture connectivity and to identify precursors of visible crack development. Determining these precursors will potentially allow one to predict rock failure and the expected mode of connectivity of hydraulic fractures before these phenomena take place. The experimental observations of this research will be the basis for further developments and validation of coupled hydro-mechanical models used to simulate the hydraulic fracturing of crystalline rocks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hydraulic fracturing of crystalline rocks has a strong potential in Enhanced Geothermal Systems (EGS) and Artificial Groundwater Recharge (AGR) applications. EGS is used to capture the heat stored deep in the Earth (usually at depths greater than 1km) and transport it to the surface to generate heating and electricity with nearly no CO2 emissions.  AGR is a method that enhances the recharge of wells at shallower depths (usually tens or hundreds of meters), which may be particularly useful to increase the supply of clean water to populations in dry regions.

However, at the field scale, the lack of fracture connectivity after the hydraulic stimulations may lead to low, or insignificant, increases in the permeability of the rock formations stimulated which, in turn, may result in financial losses and ultimately cause the abandonment of EGS and AGR projects without taking advantage of their full potential. Furthermore, the microseismicity associated with the stimulation of the rock formation has also led to the abandonment of EGS projects. Therefore, understanding the effect of variables, such as the injection rate and the triaxial state of stress, on fracture connectivity and micro-seismicity is of adamant importance to the success of these applications, since it will improve the design and implementation of the hydraulic fracturing technique in the field.

This project experimentally evaluated the effect of the injection rates and triaxial states of stress on the hydraulic fracturing processes and fracture connectivity, as well as on the microseismic activity induced by the development of hydraulic fractures in granite. For this purpose, a test setup was developed that allowed one to apply a triaxial state of stress in prismatic granite specimens measuring 6inx3inx1in and a hydraulic pressure inside a pair of prefabricated flaws while simultaneously monitoring the damaging and fracturing processes visually and through acoustic emissions. Three injection rates (0.3ml/min, 3ml/min and 30ml/min) without confinement and three triaxial states of stress (LL=2MPa; OP=2MPa; VL=1MPa, 2MPa and 4MPa, with LL – Lateral load, OP – Out-of-plane load, VL – Vertical Load) were evaluated.

The experimental results obtained under this project showed that the injection rate has a significant impact on the magnitude and location of the micro-earthquakes felt, with higher injection rates resulting in more large-magnitude events. Moreover, higher injection rates resulted in larger breakdown pressures and more complex fracturing patterns. While these observations were theoretically explained by the fact that the tests with higher injection rates supplied more energy to the rock specimens, they also indicate that controlling the injection rate in the field may mitigate the induced seismicity felt in real-scale EGS projects.

The tests conducted also showed a relationship between the triaxial state of stress and the level of connectivity between existing and hydraulically-created fractures: for uniform triaxial loadings (i.e. same stresses in all directions), no coalescence was observed, while for non-uniform triaxial stresses, direct coalescence occurred. The tests were also fundamental to understand the physical mechanisms involved in the progressive damage that leads to the creation of visible fractures. Indeed, the tests showed that micro-damage, observed as whitening of grains, precedes the visible fractures and that intragranular cracking is predominant when a uniform state of stress is applied. Fracture initiation pressure was related to a change in slope in the pressurizing rate (dPf/dt, with Pf being the pressure in the prefabricated flaws) and appears to identify fracture initiation more efficiently than visual methods; this indicates that important microscopic fracturing processes occur without visual evidence. Furthermore, the triaxial state of stress also played a fundamental role on the magnitude and location of the micro-earthquakes produced, as well as on their time variation. In fact, as opposed to the unconfined tests (i.e. conducted with different injection rates), the experiments on specimens subject to different triaxial states of stress showed that most of the micro-seismic events occurred after the hydraulic pressure in the pre-fabricated flaws was lost or released, indicating that a significant portion of the energy supplied during the test was still stored in the system and was eventually released as seismic energy once the hydraulic pressure was reduced. This implies that, in real-scale EGS projects, quickly shutting down the pumps after hydraulic fracturing operations may result in an increase in micro-seismicity due to the release of energy still stored in the rock.

In conclusion, this project yielded important, repeatable and consistent experimental observations that can be used to improve the efficiency and reduce the environmental impact of EGS and AGR operations, therefore contributing to the sustainable development of these technologies.
